notes.text:
Updated X.org packages that fix a security issue are now available for Red
Hat Enterprise Linux 4.

This update has been rated as having important security impact by the Red
Hat Security Response Team.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
X.org is an open source implementation of the X Window System. It provides
the basic low-level functionality that full-fledged graphical user
interfaces are designed upon.

iDefense reported three integer overflow flaws in the X.org Render and DBE
extensions. A malicious authorized client could exploit this issue to cause
a denial of service (crash) or potentially execute arbitrary code with root
privileges on the X.org server. (CVE-2006-6101, CVE-2006-6102, CVE-2006-6103)

Users of X.org should upgrade to these updated packages, which contain a
backported patch and is not vulnerable to this issue.

notes.text: Integer overflow in the ProcRenderAddGlyphs function in the Render extension for X.Org 6.8.2, 6.9.0, 7.0, and 7.1, and XFree86 X server, allows local users to execute arbitrary code via a crafted X protocol request that triggers memory corruption during processing of glyph management data structures.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 is not vulnerable to this issue as it contains a backported patch.
notes.title: Statement

This will start an interactive process that will result in the appropriate
RPMs being upgraded on your system.
